section.title: Downloading
section.para: First it is good to check project's home page.
Download page at SourceForge includes all files released by this project. You can go there and get the newest version.

section.title: Dependencies
section.para: This is a sophisticated software that depends on few other projects.

Common dependencies are:
C++ compiler
CORBA implementation with IDL to C++ mapping, for example MICO
compatible mail transfer agent
Sablotron if you want to compile WWW interface
boost library
DocBook and doxygen if you want to generate new version of documentation
Iconv if you want to generate WWW interface
compatible database client libraries
Cgicc library if you want to generate WWW interface

section.title: Mail transfer agent
section.para: At this time only qmail is supported. So before you begin you must install it.
We suggest you installing qmail patched using Qmail-patches. But v-q doesn't require that, you can use any version you want.
We hope that as time comes other MTAs will be supported.

section.title: PostgreSQL version
section.para: First you need to download PostgreSQL. Using newest stable version is suggested. You also need libpqxx and PERL module called Pg (if you want to use automatic installation script). All progams you can download from http://www.postgresql.org.

section.para: First step is to download and install all software pointed out in and .

section.title: Creating user and group
section.para: V-q daemon can work as any user, but it is suggested to run them under _vq group and _vq user.
You can use following commands to do that (works under Linux and OpenBSD): groupadd _vq useradd -g _vq -d /var/vq _vq

section.title: Unpacking sources
section.para: Depending on package format you can use tar, bzip2, gzip to decompress archive.

If archive's name ends with .tar.gz you can unpack it with following commands:
tar -xzvf v-q.*.tar.gz
If you tar doesn't supports gzip unpacking use:
gzip -dc v-q.*.tar.gz | tar -xvf -

If archive's name ends with .tar.bz2 you can unpack it using:
bzip2 -cd v-q.*.tar.bz2 | tar -xvf -

At this time sources are released only with specified formats.
Bzip2 gives better compression rate than gzip but it's not as popular as gzip so before downloading archive in this format check if you have it installed on your system.

section.title: Configuration before compilation
section.para: Before running make you must configure sources. There's no configure script. V-q don't use autoconf and it's family.
But don't be scared. Configuration is quite easy - all you need to do is edit few files.

First you need to set compiler and its options. In the main directory there are following files:
compile is used in normal compilation. Default version executes g++.
comp-so is used to compile objects that will be included in shared libraries. Default version executes g++ with arguments: -fpic -DPIC.
load is used to link objects. Default version executes g++.
make-lib is used to create statically linked library. It executes ar.
make-so is used to create dynamically linked library. It executes g++ with -shared option.
idl is used to process IDL definitions to C++ files. Remember that it creates 2 files with extensions: .hpp and .cc. Default version calls idl (MICO has such program).
If you use other options or programs to compile your version of v-q please send information about them to Pawe³ Niewiadomski

Next step is to edit files with extensions: .inc and .lib. First are used during compilation, they include informations about directories used in searching included files. Second are used while linking, they include references to libraries. You don't need to edit all of them. For example if you don't want to compile PostgreSQL modules you don't need to edit pgsql.inc and pgsql.lib. Usually these files include description inside them.

section.title: Compilation
section.para: Now it's time to compile sources. If you configured everything properly you should be able to successfully compile it.

To compile program use make. You can use both flavors: BSD or GNU. Depending on the shell you use you can, for sh, write:
make 2>&1 > out
If you use tcsh you can use:
make >& out
When make finishes check out to see output generated during compilation.
If you can't compile v-q please send out to Pawe³ Niewiadomski.

Running make generates only base system without any database based modules or WWW interface. Makefile includes following useful targets:
pgsql - PostgreSQL based modules
clean - removes all objects created during compilation

section.title: Installation
section.para:
After succesful compilation you're ready to install software. It's easy as writing:
./install

section.title: Special steps for Qmail
section.para: After installing v-q you can tweak some settings. For example if qmail's configuration owner is other than user running qmailvqd you can change owner and set SETUID permission for bin/qmail* programs (except qmailvqd). This will allow these programs to change qmail's configuration.

section.title: Special steps for PostgreSQL
section.para:
First you need to create user for v-q. Default user is "mail", but you can use any name. To create user you can use following command:
createuser -A -D -P mail

Then you need to create a database for v-q. Default name is "mail". But you can use any name.
createdb -E utf-8 -O mail mail

To create objects in a database you can use PERL script install.pgsql. This document doesn't desribe how to manually create them. If you don't want to use this script check it's source to see what needs to be created.
Before running this script check whether it suits you needs (for example schema name).

section.title: What if I have problems?
section.para: If you have problems installing v-q check home page, check also v-q's page on SourceForge. There you will find mailing list, forums, etc.
